questions.question: What is the primary use of the Pumping Lemma for context-free languages?

answers.a: To prove that some languages are not context-free.
answers.d: To determine closure properties of CFLs.

explanations.a: Correct! The Pumping Lemma is a tool used to prove that certain languages are not context-free.
explanations.b: Incorrect. Minimization is not the purpose of the Pumping Lemma.
explanations.c: Incorrect. The lemma is not about generating grammars.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Closure properties are studied separately.

questions.question: Which type of languages does the Pumping Lemma for CFLs specifically apply to?

explanations.a: Incorrect. The lemma is not universal to all formal languages.
explanations.b: Incorrect. Regular languages have their own Pumping Lemma.
explanations.c: Correct! This Pumping Lemma applies to context-free languages.
explanations.d: Incorrect. It does not apply to context-sensitive languages.

questions.question: When applying the Pumping Lemma for CFLs, a string S is divided into five parts: S = uvxyz. Which condition must always hold?

answers.c: u and z must always be empty
answers.d: v and y must be identical substrings

explanations.a: Correct! At least one of v or y must be non-empty so that 'pumping' has an effect.
explanations.b: Correct! Another key condition is that the middle portion vxy has length at most p.
explanations.c: Incorrect. u and z can be empty or non-empty.
explanations.d: Incorrect. v and y are not required to be identical.

questions.question: What does 'pumping' a string in the context of the Pumping Lemma mean?

answers.a: Repeating the substrings v and y any number of times while keeping u, x, and z fixed.
answers.b: Generating new productions in the grammar.

explanations.a: Correct! Pumping means repeating (or removing) the parts v and y while keeping the rest unchanged.
explanations.b: Incorrect. Pumping does not add productions.
explanations.c: Incorrect. This refers to grammar transformations, not pumping.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Pumping Lemma does not address ambiguity.

questions.question: Which of the following languages can be proven NOT to be context-free using the Pumping Lemma?

explanations.a: Correct! The language a^n b^n c^n is not context-free and can be proven so using the Pumping Lemma.
explanations.c: Incorrect. a^i b^j is context-free (regular in fact).
explanations.d: Correct! The language ww^R is not context-free and can also be shown using the Pumping Lemma.

questions.question: What limitation of the Pumping Lemma should be kept in mind when using it?

answers.a: It can only prove that a language is not context-free, not that it is context-free.
answers.b: It always requires a deterministic grammar.
answers.c: It applies only to finite languages.
answers.d: It guarantees closure properties of CFLs.

explanations.a: Correct! The Pumping Lemma is a negative test — it can prove non-context-freeness but cannot prove context-freeness.
explanations.b: Incorrect. Determinism is not a requirement.
explanations.c: Incorrect. It does not apply only to finite languages.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Closure properties are proven by separate theorems.
